passages.text: Equity Research European General Retail 29 August 2025
**1H preview (due 23 Sep)**

1H due 23 Sep (covering Feb-Jul). We forecast 2Q group LFL growth of -0.5%, with the slowdown from +2.7% in 1Q driven by the UK, reflecting pulled forward demand. We forecast 1H PBT of £331m. We expect Kingfisher may trim the lower end of its PBT guidance range (c.£480m to £540m).

**Kingfisher is due to report 1H25/26 results on Tuesday, 23 September - covering the** **six months to 31 July.** We forecast 2Q group LFL sales at -0.5% compared with company-collected consensus of +0.1% (as of 17 July). This would mark a sequential slowdown from +2.7% in 1Q, which was supported by strong seasonal category growth in the UK amid very favourable weather in spring. We expect demand was pulled forward from 2Q into 1Q,particularly in 'once a season' categories (e.g. barbecues). We expect slight sequential improvement in France, driven mainly by softer comps, though still expect low single-digit LFL decline. We expect continued weakness in Poland (-3% LFL), primarily reflecting unseasonally wet and cold weather.

We expect Kingfisher may trim the bottom end of the FY25/26 PBT guidance range (c.£480m to £540m) given another four months will have passed since the last update, and we suspect 1H was reasonably strong in terms of profitability in the UK. We forecast FY25/26 PBT of £522m. Our 1H25/26 PBT forecast of £331m is in line with consensus and implies a 64/36 1H/2H weighting,sightly more 1H weighted than average in recent years to reflect the expected strong UK sales outcome.

**We update our model for revised expectations, FX moves and executed share buybacks.** We are very slightly more cautious on LFL sales and margins, which is offset by favourable FX moves and a lower diluted WASO (buybacks at lower price and more 1H weighted than forecast). The net effect is that our EPS estimates fall -0.4% for FY25/26, but rise a touch for FY26/27 (+0.3%)and FY27/28 (+0.6%). Our valuation of Kingfisher is driven by an average of a sum-of-the-parts valuation and a DCF. This remains unchanged at 280p. Reiterate UW.

Kingfisher – 1H25/26 preview
FIGURE 1. Kingfisher – LFL sales growth, 21/22-25/26
Latest company-compiled consensus: 17 July 2025
Source: Company data, Barclays Research estimates
FIGURE 2. Kingfisher - Headline performance measures
Latest company-compiled consensus: 17 July 2025 Source: Company data, Barclays Research estimates
We outline our 1H25/26 sales expectations below. As a reminder, Kingfisher did not provide a current trading update with 1Q results in late May.

- 1Q25/26 LFL sales supported by favourable weather. UK & Ireland 1Q25/26 LFL was \(+5.9\%\) split between \(+7.9\%\) at B&Q and \(+2.9\%\) at Screwfix. Compared to low single digit market growth. Seasonal category LFL of \(+28.3\% (+29.8\% B\& Q / +21.2\% Screwfix)\) , compared with Core \(+1.5\%\) and and Big-ticket \(+2.5\%\) .

- Barclays Spend Trends 2.0 data (Figure 3). The data indicates that the market deteriorated in Kingfisher's 2Q, with the 'Home Supply Warehouse' signal showing a sequential slowdown of nearly 8ppts from 1Q. The signal under-read the market in 1Q (indicating MSD market decline vs Kingfisher's observed LSD market growth).
- B&Q \((+0.5\% 2Q25 / 26E\) LFL sales, vs consensus \(+1.7\%\)

- Wicks 1H trading update - positive read-across for Kingfisher's B&Q banner. UK home improvement retailer Wicks (not covered) reported a 1H trading update on 24 July, covering the six months to June. Retail LFL growth accelerated to \(+7.9\%\) in 2Q (vs \(+4.4\%\) in 1Q). Growth was volume driven, with prices broadly stable. Particularly strong demand across timber, garden maintenance and decorating, with market share during 1H at record highs. Within Retail, TradePro remained strong at \(+10\%\) in 1H, with active members up \(+14\%\) YOY. DIY sales grew mid-single digit in 1H - volume driven. Wicks said 1H performance reflects some support from warm spring weather and Easter timing. Wicks is flagging tougher comps in 2H. Elsewhere, Design & Installation LFL accelerated to \(+3.5\%\) (vs \(-5.6\%\) in 1Q), with a third consecutive quarter of growth in ordered sales. Wicks remains comfortable with current consensus expectations for adjusted PBT in 2025 of £48.3m, with a range of £46.7-51.5m. This compares with consensus of £47.7m, with a range of £45.6-51.0m, in early May.

- We expect... Kingfisher to report 2Q25/26E LFL of -1.0% at B&Q, a slowdown from +7.9% in 1Q25/26 reflecting the pull-forward in demand due to very favourable weather in 1Q. We note than our forecasts imply a 1H25/26E B&Q LFL of +3.2% - a good outcome for a banner which barely grown over the last three years.
- Screwfix \((0.0\% 2Q25 / 26E\) LFL sales, vs consensus \(+1.6\%\)

- Toolstation read-across. Travis Perkins (covered by Rajesh Patki) reported 1H results covering the six months to June. Toolstation UK (key peer of Kingfisher's Screwfix) sales grew \(+5\%\) in 1H25 (adjusted for trading days), driven by "modest price inflation and good volume growth". This indicates market share gains. Total Toolstation (incl. Benelux) LFL sales growth slowed from \(+3.7\%\) in 1Q to \(+2.3\%\) in 2Q. UK adjusted EBIT grew by \(+50\%\) to £21m, with operating margin expanding by \(+180\) bps to \(5.7\%\) driven by further improvements in the gross margin mix and supply chain efficiencies.
- We expect... Kingfisher to report 2Q25/26E LFLs of 0.0% at Screwfix, a slowdown from +2.9% in 1Q25/26. Again, primarily reflecting pull-forward of demand into 1Q.
FIGURE 3. Barclays Spend Trends 2.0 - DIY signal vs B&Q and Screwfix sales growth
Home Supply Warehouse Stores' B&Q and Screwfix total sales growth Source: Barclays Research, Barclays UK Spend Trends 2.0

- 1Q25/26 LFL sales less impacted by weather. France 1Q25/26 LFL was -3.2%, split between -3.0% at Castorama and -3.3% at Brico Depot, compared to mid single digit market decline. Weather was not as material a factor in 1Q for France as it was for the UK, with seasonal category LFL growth of +1.6% (+0.6% Castorama / +2.9% Brico Depot), compared with Core -5.0% and Big-ticket -3.1%.

- Banque de France Hardware DIY data (Figure 4). Volume decline averaged c. -4% in 2Q (similar to 1Q) with +1.5% in May and -9.5% in July. Value decline averaged c. -3% (vs c. -3.5% in 1Q), with a c. 1ppt positive price impact.

- Comps do seem to get softer. The BdF data indicates a similar MSD contraction in market in 2Q as indicated for 1Q. The BdF 'Hardware DIY' comps do get 2-3ppts softer, but Castorama saw a 4ppt sequential slowdown from 1Q into 2Q last year, while Brico Depot saw a 3ppt sequential slowdown. We suspect, therefore, that Kingfisher may benefit from softer comps in 2Q25/26.
- Castorama France (-1.5% 2Q25/26 LFL sales vs consensus -2.6%). We expect... Kingfisher to report 2Q25 LFL of -1.5% at Castorama France, an improvement from -3.0% in 1Q25/26.
- Brico Dépôt France (-2.0% 2Q25/26 LFL sales vs consensus -2.8%). We expect... Kingfisher to report 2Q25 LFL of -2.0% at Brico Dépôt France, an improvement from -3.3% in 1Q25/26.
FIGURE 4. BdF data suggests the French DIY market remained in MSD decline in 2Q
Source: Barclays Research, Banque de France
- Unhelpful weather. 2Q was cold and wet in Poland, which we expect weighed on seasonal category sales (-0.4% LFL in 1Q vs Poland overall -3.2%).

- Subdued consumer environment. Polish retailers such as Jeronimo Martins and Dino Polska report cautious consumer behaviour. Mortgage rates remain high. Uncertainty around the presidential elections may have weighed on big-ticket purchases. That said, GUS retail sales data indicates most categories saw sequentially better volume growth in Kingfisher's 2Q.
- Castorama Poland (-3.0% 2QE LFL sales vs consensus -0.8%). We expect... Kingfisher to report 2Q25/26 LFL of -3.0% at Castorama Polska, broadly in line with -3.2% in 1Q25/26.

In Figure 9, we summarise the small changes we have made to our Kingfisher forecasts. We are slightly more cautious on LFL sales and margins, which is offset by favourable FX moves and a lower diluted WASO (buybacks at lower price and more 1H weighted than forecast). The net effect is that our EPS estimates fall \(- 0.4\%\) for FY25/26, but rise a touch for FY26/27 (+0.3%) and FY27/28 (+0.6%).
Our valuation of Kingfisher is driven by an average of a sum- of- the- parts valuation and a DCF. This remains unchanged at 280p.

Kingfisher - Questions for management- To what extent do new Screwfix stores take sales away from existing B&Q stores?- The target of 1,000 Screwfix stores in UK/Ireland should be hit relatively soon. Are you starting to think that the UK has capacity for more than 1,000 stores, or do you need to shift attention to smaller format locations?- How confident are you about Screwfix's price positioning versus Toolstation?- Why do you expect Screwfix to work in France when it proved unsuccessful in Germany? The rate of new store openings planned for 2025/26 does not seem to suggest great optimism.- French margins deteriorated further in FY24/25 (from 3.3% to 2.4%). Presumably, ongoing sales declines have caused some deleverage. Are there any reasons for encouragement on industry trends within the French market?- Trade has been a big area of growth in recent years. How confident are you this is really incremental sales? Is there a risk that some of the apparent sales growth is just reclassification of existing customers?- To what extent have marketplaces like ManoMano taken share in markets like France? Do you see any sign of them taking noticeable share in the UK so far?- You now have over 100 stores in Poland and are targeting 75 medium-box and compact store openings over the next 4/5 years in that country. How many stores would it take to achieve complete coverage of the Polish market? What is the shape of the 75-store rollout? And what, roughly, do you expect the split will be between medium-box and compact stores?- What is your latest assessment of how the Polish business is being affected by the Ukraine crisis?- Beyond your core markets (i.e., UK, France, Poland), which of your other geographies seem to offer the most opportunity? What is your early assessment regarding the franchise and wholesale opportunity in other markets?- Your FCF guidance seems to require ongoing help from working capital inflows. How do you see your inventory levels versus peers? Is that the biggest opportunity?- What is your freehold property ownership by market? Do you consider the current level of ownership to be appropriate?- Excluding leases, Kingfisher seems to be in a steady net cash position. Is that an efficient position for the balance sheet?- Which macro-economic indicators do you tend to watch most closely? What do you find to be the most encouraging / concerning data points at the moment?- What is the appropriate balance between brand autonomy and group scale?- You have set targets for retail media income. Are you confident that this is already additive to group PBT?

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: As with all the companies we cover, we use a discounted cash flow (DCF) methodology to value Kingfisher. We also use a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) methodology given that Kingfisher comprises a number of businesses with quite different growth characteristics and margin structures. Our price target is the average of the DCF and SOTP. In our DCF we assume terminal sales growth of \(2.3\%\) (in line with what we expect in the final year of our explicit forecasts) and a terminal EBITDA margin of \(11.0\%\) . We use a WACC of \(9.7\%\) . In our SOTP for most of the segments we start

by applying an EV/sales multiple, but we choose that multiple with reference to the implied EV/EBIT multiple it generates for 25/26E. (We tend to prefer EV/EBIT rather than EV/EBITDA because of the different capital intensities of the various segments.) We apply higher multiples to the faster growing businesses, notably Screwfix and stores in Poland, although we also use higher multiples for the segments where we still see recovery potential (e.g. Castorama France).

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: The main risks to the upside include the following: Lower interest rates could stimulate the housing market and create demand for home improvement products. If we get evidence of the Screwfix model working well in France then this could create hopes of a long- term profitable rollout opportunity. French and Polish margins have reduced sharply in the last few years - if we see signs of recovery then this may create hope of sustained improvement. The main risks to the downside include the following: Screwfix is starting to open stores in France; if this move does not go well then the market might reconsider the banner's long- term growth potential. Kingfisher sources \(20\%\) of its goods in US dollars - a sharp rise in the value of the USD against either or both GBP/EUR would likely put some pressure on earnings. The global supply chain has encountered various blockages in recent years and if any further problems emerge then this could be a challenge for Kingfisher.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

IRS Circular 230 Prepared Materials Disclaimer: Barclays does not provide tax advice and nothing contained herein should be construed to be tax advice. Please be advised that any discussion of U.S. tax matters contained herein (including any attachments) (i) is not intended or written to be used, and cannot be used, by you for the purpose of avoiding U.S. tax- related penalties; and (ii) was written to support the promotion or marketing of the transactions or other matters addressed herein. Accordingly, you should seek advice based on your particular circumstances from an independent tax advisor.
